Class Odometer

  • java.lang.Object
    • Odometer

  • public class Odometer
extends java.lang.Object
    Odometer running in background will keep track of proprioception.

    The odometer runs in standard co-ordinates (ISO 80000-2:2009) with the branch cut (-Pi, Pi] (we don't want a branch cut in our small angle approximations about zero) eg counter-clockwise radians from x; this is the same used in Math.atan2 and all trig and grade school. The travelTo (and turnTo) take degrees and convert them to radians; it's much faster converting them once vs converting atan2 10 times a second.

    This is the improved, non-numerically-unstable int math odometer./** Odometer running in background will keep track of proprioception.

    fixme: if we run the robot faster, the period should decrese

    The x and y orientation is identical to that used in the labs. However, theta=0 starts at the x-axis instead of the y-axis, and increments counterclockwise and opposed to clockwise. The conversion is old_theta = -new_theta + 90 and conversly new_theta = -old_theta + 90. -Alex

    Author:
    Neil

    • Method Detail

      • shutdown

        public void shutdown()
        shuts down the odometer so it isn't taking data (it currently has no method to start it again)

      • timedOut

        public void timedOut()
        this goes every ODO_DELAY ms until it is shutdown(); just adds the little bit to the odometer

      • positionSnapshot

        public void positionSnapshot()
        Deprecated. 
        this stores a copy of the actal position (which is volitale) in pCopy; pCopy is called when reading position . . . viz you must call this to update position used in getPosition, but only once per movement; you will probably want to call premonitionUpdate() instead to get rid of one-sided errors
        See Also:
        premonitionUpdate()

      • premonitionUpdate

        public void premonitionUpdate()
        this eliminates one-sided errors by predicting the future; also this stores a copy of the actal position (which is volitale) in pCopy; pCopy is called when reading position . . . you must call this instead of positionSnapshot
